meta.title: Wheel of Life Assessment: Resources Layer
meta.definition: The logical produce of skill; surplus in the forms of money, time, energy, knowledge, and relational capital that can be stewarded and reinvested for ongoing value. Not just having enough — having MORE than enough.
meta.relationship_to_other_layers: Resources are produced by Skill (Layer 5). If Resources are lacking, check if Skill is developed — you can't generate surplus without competence. Resources enable Fellowship (Layer 7) — you need something to bring to mutual relationships, and they enable Sacrifice (Layer 8) — you can only give away what you have.
meta.key_principle: We are commanded to give away our second cloak, never our first. Maintain your foundation; steward your surplus.

calculation.method: Sum dimension questions, divide by 5, multiply by 2

1-2.label: Crisis
1-2.description: Poverty — consuming more than producing; immediate attention required

3-4.label: Below Baseline
3-4.description: Subsistence — barely enough, no surplus to work with

5-6.label: Maintaining
5-6.description: Stability — needs are met but little margin

7-8.label: Target Zone
7-8.description: Surplus — generating more than consuming, able to invest

9-10.label: Exceptional
9-10.description: Abundance — significant surplus available for giving and investing

dimensions.name: Communion
dimensions.description: Having spiritual surplus — not just getting by spiritually, but having overflow to draw from and share

scripture_anchor.text: Out of his heart will flow rivers of living water.

questions.text: I have spiritual reserves I can draw on in difficult times — my tank is not perpetually near empty.
I have accumulated spiritual insights, experiences, and wisdom that I can share with others.
My spiritual life generates more than it consumes — I'm not constantly depleted, running on fumes.
I have developed a relationship with God deep enough that I have something real to offer others seeking Him.
My prayer life, Scripture knowledge, and spiritual practices have accumulated into a resource I can deploy.

remediation.advice: Spiritual surplus comes from consistent investment over time. If you're always running on empty, you're either not investing enough (discipline/skill issue) or you're giving away your first cloak (boundary issue). Build reserves before increasing output.

scripture.text: I have stored up your word in my heart, that I might not sin against you.

dimensions.name: Conscience
dimensions.description: Having moral capital — accumulated trust, integrity, and credibility that gives weight to your words and actions

scripture_anchor.text: A good name is to be chosen rather than great riches, and favor is better than silver or gold.

questions.text: I have built a reputation for integrity that precedes me — people trust my word before I speak.
questions.principle: Moral capital is accumulated through consistent action

questions.text: I have relational credit built up from past faithfulness that I could draw on if needed.
My track record of keeping commitments gives me credibility when I make new ones.
I have enough moral standing that people come to me for ethical guidance or as a character reference.
My integrity has compounded over time into a genuine asset — doors open because of who I've proven to be.

remediation.advice: Moral capital is built one kept promise at a time. If you lack credibility, the answer isn't marketing — it's accumulating a track record. Every commitment kept is a deposit. Every promise broken is a withdrawal. Build the account.

scripture.text: The integrity of the upright guides them, but the crookedness of the treacherous destroys them.

dimensions.name: Holiness
dimensions.description: Having spiritual health reserves — enough purity and strength to weather temptation and help others in their battles

scripture_anchor.text: Brothers, if anyone is caught in any transgression, you who are spiritual should restore him in a spirit of gentleness.

questions.text: I have enough spiritual strength that I can help others fight their battles without being pulled down myself.
questions.principle: Spiritual surplus enables ministry to others

questions.text: I have built up enough resistance to temptation that I'm not constantly in survival mode spiritually.
My spiritual health is robust enough to absorb setbacks without crisis — I have margin.
I have accumulated enough victory over specific sins that I can mentor others facing the same battles.
My spiritual immune system is strong — exposure to darkness doesn't destabilize me the way it once did.
questions.principle: Spiritual strength develops through tested exposure

remediation.advice: Spiritual health reserves are built through Layer 4 (discipline) and Layer 5 (skill) applied consistently. If you're always in survival mode, you're either under-investing or over-extending. Establish your foundation before expanding your exposure.

scripture.text: But solid food is for the mature, for those who have their powers of discernment trained by constant practice.

dimensions.name: Mind
dimensions.description: Having intellectual capital — accumulated knowledge, wisdom, and mental frameworks that you can apply and share

scripture_anchor.text: The wise lay up knowledge, but the mouth of a fool brings ruin near.

questions.text: I have accumulated knowledge that others find valuable — people seek my expertise or perspective.
questions.principle: Knowledge becomes capital when others value it

questions.text: I have mental models and frameworks that help me navigate situations I haven't seen before.
I can teach or explain things in my areas of competence — my knowledge is organized enough to transfer.
I have intellectual reserves to draw on — I'm not always scrambling to figure things out from scratch.
My thinking has produced insights, systems, or content that has value beyond my personal use.

remediation.advice: Intellectual capital is built through Layer 5 (skill in learning and thinking) applied over time. If you're always scrambling, invest in developing expertise in fewer areas rather than shallow knowledge in many. Depth produces surplus; breadth often produces scarcity.

scripture.text: An intelligent heart acquires knowledge, and the ear of the wise seeks knowledge.

dimensions.name: Will
dimensions.description: Having capacity surplus — the bandwidth, energy, and follow-through ability to take on more than the minimum

scripture_anchor.text: I can do all things through him who strengthens me.

questions.text: I have capacity beyond what's required to maintain my current life — I could take on more if needed.
My systems and habits are efficient enough that I have time and energy left over.
I'm not constantly maxed out — I have reserves of willpower and execution capacity.
I have developed enough personal productivity that I accomplish more than most with similar time.
I have margin in my schedule and energy — unexpected demands don't automatically create crisis.

remediation.advice: Capacity surplus comes from skill in execution (Layer 5) plus boundaries (not over-committing). If you're perpetually maxed out, either your skill is lacking (you're inefficient) or your boundaries are (you're saying yes to too much). Fix the root cause.

scripture.text: The plans of the diligent lead surely to abundance, but everyone who is hasty comes only to poverty.

dimensions.name: Emotions
dimensions.description: Having emotional bandwidth — enough stability and reserve to handle your own emotions AND be present for others

scripture_anchor.text: Rejoice with those who rejoice, weep with those who weep.

questions.text: I have emotional reserves — I can absorb difficulty without immediately destabilizing.
I have enough emotional stability to be present for others' emotions without being overwhelmed.
I'm not constantly emotionally depleted — I have energy for connection and relationship.
I've processed enough of my own baggage that I'm not triggered by everyone else's.
I have developed emotional wealth — peace, joy, contentment — that overflows to others.

remediation.advice: Emotional surplus comes from processing your own stuff (Layer 5 emotional skill) and maintaining boundaries. If you're always emotionally depleted, you're either not processing (accumulating debt) or not protecting (giving away your first cloak). Address the leak.

scripture.text: A tranquil heart gives life to the flesh, but envy makes the bones rot.

dimensions.name: Sustenance
dimensions.description: Having physical provision surplus — enough food, rest, and environmental quality that you're not constantly in deficit

scripture_anchor.text: And God is able to make all grace abound to you, so that having all sufficiency in all things at all times, you may abound in every good work.

questions.text: I have consistent access to quality nutrition — I'm not constantly compromising due to scarcity or poor planning.
I get enough quality sleep that I have energy reserves, not just enough to get by.
My living environment supports rather than drains me — it's a resource, not a liability.
questions.principle: Environment can add or subtract energy

questions.text: I have financial margin for quality food, proper rest, and environmental maintenance.
My physical recovery consistently exceeds my physical expenditure — I'm building reserves, not depleting them.

remediation.advice: Physical provision surplus requires both skill (knowing what your body needs) and financial/time resources to provide it. If you're constantly running a deficit, identify whether it's knowledge, money, time, or priority that's the bottleneck.

scripture.text: It is in vain that you rise up early and go late to rest, eating the bread of anxious toil; for he gives to his beloved sleep.

dimensions.name: Capability
dimensions.description: Having physical capacity surplus — strength, endurance, and capability beyond what's required for daily life

scripture_anchor.text: He gives power to the faint, and to him who has no might he increases strength.

questions.text: My physical capability exceeds what my daily life requires — I have reserves for the unexpected.
I can physically help others (move, lift, serve) because I have capacity beyond my own needs.
My fitness level gives me options — I can hike, travel, play, work physically if needed.
I'm building physical capacity rather than just maintaining or losing it — investing, not just spending.
I have energy left at the end of the day — I'm not completely depleted by normal activities.

remediation.advice: Physical capacity surplus is built through consistent training (discipline) and smart training (skill). If your physical capability is barely enough for daily life, you're one injury or illness away from crisis. Build margin through progressive training.

scripture.text: Do you not know that in a race all the runners run, but only one receives the prize? So run that you may obtain it.

dimensions.name: Wholeness
dimensions.description: Having health reserves — robust enough wellness that you can absorb setbacks and still function well

scripture_anchor.text: Beloved, I pray that all may go well with you and that you may be in good health, as it goes well with your soul.

questions.text: My health is robust enough to absorb a setback (illness, injury, stress) without cascade failure.
I recover from illness or injury faster than average — my body has resources to heal.
My overall wellness creates capacity for life rather than limiting it.
questions.principle: Health is enabling, not just absence of disease

questions.text: I have invested in preventive care and maintenance that is paying dividends in current health.
My integrated health (body, soul, spirit) creates synergy — each area supports the others rather than dragging them down.

remediation.advice: Health reserves are built through all previous layers: order (believing health follows patterns), causality (seeing cause-effect), responsibility (owning your health), discipline (consistent practices), and skill (knowing what works). If reserves are low, trace back to find the weak link.

scripture.text: And the God of peace will sanctify you completely, and may your whole spirit and soul and body be kept blameless.

overall_interpretation.crisis: Any dimension scoring 1-4 indicates poverty in that area — you're consuming more than you're producing, or just barely surviving. Without surplus, you have nothing to invest and nothing to give. Address the skill and discipline issues that are preventing resource generation.
overall_interpretation.maintenance: Dimensions scoring 5-6 show stability but no margin. You're meeting needs but not building surplus. This is sustainable short-term but leaves you vulnerable to disruption and unable to invest in growth or give to others.
overall_interpretation.strength: Dimensions scoring 7+ show genuine surplus. You're producing more than you consume and have resources to steward. Now check if Fellowship (Layer 7) is following — are you bringing your surplus into mutual relationships?
overall_interpretation.integration: Resources apply across all domains. Financial surplus without relational capital is poverty in what matters most. Physical resources without spiritual reserves leaves you vulnerable. Build surplus in all areas, flowing upward per the Ladder of Wealth: money → time → relationships (eternal).

next_steps: Identify areas of poverty (consuming more than producing) vs surplus (producing more than consuming)
For poverty areas, trace back: is Skill lacking? Discipline? Go down the layers.
For surplus areas, ask: Am I stewarding this well? Investing? Or hoarding?
Check if you're giving away your first cloak anywhere — depleting your foundation rather than giving from surplus
Where resources are strong, check if Fellowship (Layer 7) is following
results_guidance.relationship_to_skill: Skill without resources is competence that isn't producing — you can do it well but it's not generating surplus. Resources without skill is unsustainable — you have surplus now but you're not building the competence to maintain it. Both are needed: skill produces; resources accumulate.
results_guidance.ladder_of_wealth_application: Resources exist in three tiers: money (most basic), time (more limited), relationships (most eternal). Surplus should flow upward: use money surplus to buy back time; use time surplus to invest in relationships. Don't hoard at lower levels when you could be investing at higher ones.
